transcript.title: STATEMENT BY THE PRIME MINISTER, THE HON P.J. KEATING, MP PUBLIC AWARENESS OF MABO
transcript.content:
PRIME MINISTER 87/ 93
STATEMENT BY TIlE PRIME MINIS'TER, THE HON P. J. KEATING, MP
PUBLIC AWARENESS OF MABO
I was pleased to note today that an opinion poll has found that Australians broadly
understand the limits of the High Court Mabo decision, and that it does not pose a
threat to backyards, or other privately-owned property.
While I have never been one to rely absolutely on the findings of such surveys, it is
reassuring to learn that an overwhelming majority of people have seen through the
scaremongering. It confirms my confidence in the common sense and fair-mindedness
of Australians.
Only seven per cent of those surveyed said they believed the Mabo judgement entitled
Aborigines to claim " any" land in Australia, including metropolitan land. Of course,
they are ill-informed.
As the Government has maintained since the handing down of the Mabo judgement last
year, the decision does not threaten private property rights, and should be viewed as an
opportunity rather than as a problem.
My Government continues to work and make progress towards a sensible
administrative response to the Mabo decision a response which will balance the
interests of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders with the broad national economic
interest. We are continuing to consult with the States and, as I have said before, we intend to be
in a position to introduce Commonwealth legislation during the Budget session of
Parliament, commencing on August 17.
CANBERRA 4 AUGUST, 1993
